com.gnahraf.io.store.table.merge

Class BaseMergeSource<S extends BaseMergeSource<?>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gnahraf.io.store.table.merge.BaseMergeSource<S>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<S>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ListMergeSource, PrecedenceMergeSource

    public abstract class BaseMergeSource<S extends BaseMergeSource<?>>
extends Object
implements Comparable<S>
    We maintain a stack of these in a multiway merge. A merge source encapsulates progress from a single table. These are mutually comparable in a way that allows us to easily track rows from which source table must be copied to the target of a merge.

    Here's the basic idea how works in ASCII art..

    Let's say we have 3 sorted tables we want to merge. In order to keep the sketch simple, let's say no 2 rows across any of the tables compare equal.: 

     
   E       B       I
   F       C       J
   L       G       M
           H       P
           K       Q
           Z       U
                   X
                   Y
    Each column above stands for a sorted table, and each letter in a column stands for the value of a row in that table. A merge source instance is just a wrapper around a table along with a cursor indicating the current (unmerged) row. Here are the same tables, wrapped as merge sources, and sorted in their natural order: 
     
   I<       E<        B<
   J        F         C
   M        L         G
   P                  H
   Q                  K
   U                  Z
   X
   Y
    Each merge source's cursor is initialized to its table's first row (row number zero). Merge sources are ordered based on the comparing the the row each points to with that of another. The ordering is actually in reverse, in order to more efficiently support tail end removal of merge sources from lists (an optimization, likely not worth the extra cognitive load it introduces). The diagram above exactly depicts this ordering. The tail end of the list of merge sources points to the next row to be written out to the output table. So you can view this ordering of merge sources as a kind of stack with the tail end of the list representing what must be worked on next.

    Let's call the tail merge source (far right) in the list the top merge source, and the one immediately to the left of it, the next merge source.

    The first step in the merge is to compute the index of the next's row in top. This is the row number in top where where next's current row would have found itself if it had been solely merged into top's table. In our example, the index evaluates to 2. Note this calculation is O(log n). Next, all the rows between the tops current row number and the index are block-transfered to the output file. 

     
   I<       E< --     B<                             B
   J        F    |    C                              C
   M        L     --> G  (row # 2)
   P                  H
   Q                  K
   U                  Z
   X
   Y
    The situation is depicted above after the rows in top have been transfered to output (far right column).

    Next the top merge source's cursor (row number) is set to the index noted in the previous step and the merge sources are resorted: 

     
   I<       B         E<                             B
   J        C         F                              C
   M        G<        L
   P        H         
   Q        K         
   U        Z        
   X
   Y

    The above 2 steps are repeated until the top's cursor points beyond its last row. In that event, the top merge source is removed from the list. Processing then resumes until there is but one merge source remaining in the list. The next few steps, are depicted below.. 

       I<       B         E<                             B
   J        C         F                              C
   M        G<      > L                              E
   P        H                                        F
   Q        K         
   U        Z        
   X
   Y
 

       E        I<        B                              B
   F        J         C                              C
   L<       M         G<                             E
            P         H                              F
            Q       > K                              G
            U         Z                              H
            X
            Y

    Finally, when there's only one merge source remaining in the list of merge sources, the remaining rows in that merge source are appended to the output file.

    Don't access concurrently

    Designed for single threaded access (not even concurrent reads).

    Note

    Don't be daunted by the self-referential type parameter S: it just says that derived instances are mutually comparable.
    Author:
    Babak

      • searcher

        public final SortedTable.Searcher searcher()

      • table

        public final SortedTable table()

      • rowNumber

        public long rowNumber()
        Indicates the current row number. If in the range [0, rowCount - 1], then the contents of that row number is given by row().
        Returns:
        a number between -1 and rowCount()

      • setRow

        public void setRow(long rowNum)
            throws IOException
        Sets the rowNumber() and loads the corresponding row(); unless the rowNum argument is equal to either #getRowCount() or -1, in which case the instance is considered finished.
        Throws:
        IndexOutOfBoundsException
        IOException

      • advanceRow

        public boolean advanceRow()
                   throws IOException
        Advances to the next row, unless already at the end of this merge source.
        Returns:
        true, if advanced to the next existing row; false, if advanced, or already advanced, past the last row, i.e. if finished().
        Throws:
        IOException

      • rewindRow

        public boolean rewindRow()
                  throws IOException
        Rewinds to the previous row, unless already at the beginning of this merge source.
        Returns:
        true, if advanced to the previous existing row; false, if rewound, or already rewound, past the first row, i.e. if finished().
        Throws:
        IOException

      • rowCount

        public final long rowCount()
        Returns the snapshot row count. (If there are concurrent additions to the underlying table, those will be ignored.)
        Returns:

      • row

        public final ByteBuffer row()
        Returns the contents of the current rowNumber(), if the instance is not finished(); otherwise, the return value is undefined. The returned instance is a new read-only view onto the current row. Its contents will be automatically modified every time the row number is changed.

      • copyRowInto

        public void copyRowInto(ByteBuffer buffer)
        Copies the contents of the current row into the given buffer. Slightly more efficient

      • finished

        public final boolean finished()
        An instance is finished when all its rows have been copied to the target. I.e. when rowNumber() == rowCount().

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object

        protected StringBuilder appendToStringFields(StringBuilder string)

      • compareToImpl

        protected int compareToImpl(BaseMergeSource<?> other)

      • compareRowWithOther

        public int compareRowWithOther(ByteBuffer otherRow)
        Compares this instance's row with the otherRow. This is functionally equivalent to 
         
 source = .. // a BaseMergeSource
 source.table().order().compare(source.row(), otherRow)
        except that it's marginally more efficient.

      • compareOtherWithRow

        public final int compareOtherWithRow(ByteBuffer otherRow)
        Compares the otherRow to this instance's row. This is functionally equivalent to 
         
 source = .. // a BaseMergeSource
 source.table().order().compare(otherRow, source.row())
        except that it's marginally more efficient.
        Returns:
        -compareRowWithOther(otherRow)
